I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has long supported reforms to banking and rural 
finance and microfinance in the Lao People's Democratic Republic (Lao PDR). The Banking 
Sector Reform Program (BSRP)1 was completed in the first quarter of 2009. The program 
supported recapitalization of state-owned commercial banks (SOCBs) matched with governance 
agreements to insulate the banks from political interference in their commercial operations. 
Other activities have included reforming banking laws and improving private sector access to 
credit.  The  following  lessons  drawn  from  the  banking  reform  program  are  relevant  to  the 
proposed technical assistance (TA)2: (i) political support and macroeconomic stability are crucial 
to the success of development assistance programs in the finance sector; (ii) strong governance 
at the Bank of the Lao PDR (BOL) is fundamental for an effective prudential supervisory 
framework,  and  therefore  a  sound  banking  sector;  and  (iii)  sufficient  TA  resources  are 
necessary to support sustained capacity development at the BOL and other financial institutions. 
A completed TA cluster on rural finance3 introduced the concept of sustainable rural finance to 
the Lao PDR finance sector and undertook initial sector reforms. The ongoing Rural Finance 
Sector Development Program (RFSDP)4 aims to restructure the Agriculture Promotion Bank 
(APB),  develop  grassroots  microfinance  institutions  (MFIs),  and  build  BOL  microfinance 
supervision. The program is on track for completion in March 2011.  
 
2.  While the banking sector has improved substantially in the past 3 years, the finance 
sector is among the shallowest in Southeast Asia and intermediation is limited. Governance in 
the finance sector has improved, but it remains weak by regional standards. In particular, 
supervisory capacity at the BOL, including its anti-money laundering (AML) regime, is limited, as 
is financial disclosure and private monitoring of banks and microfinance institutions (MFIs). MFIs 
are expanding, which has created additional challenges in banking supervision. Although the 
recent global financial crisis has had a limited impact on the Lao PDR finance sector, it has 
highlighted  the  weaknesses  in  finance  sector  regulations  and  supervision.  Further,  it  has 
underscored the need to build the BOL's capacity to cope with future situations when the sector 
is more integrated with regional and global financial markets. The recently approved financial 
sector  strategy  of  Lao  PDR5 prioritizes  capacity  development  in  supervision.  The  strategy 
includes  six  components:  (i)  banking  sector  development,  covering  prudential  supervision, 
intermediation, and branching; (ii) development of nonbank financial institutes; (iii) microfinance 
institutions (MFIs); (iv) money markets; (v) capital markets; and (vi) finance sector infrastructure. 
The strategy identifies short-term priorities including banking sector development in prudential 
supervision and branching and expansion of rural finance coverage; and longer-term priorities 
such as the establishment of interbank lending. The proposed TA is aligned with the objectives 
of the strategy relating to prudential supervision.  
 
3.  Thus, it is an opportune time to build on previous and ongoing ADB programs to further 
strengthen the BOL's governance through capacity development in supervision. The purpose of 
this TA is threefold: (i) strengthen capacity development for effective supervision of commercial

4.  The proposed TA has been included in the Lao PDR country operations business plan, 
2009–2011.6 The  fact-finding  missions  that  visited  Lao  PDR  in  April  2009  and  May  2009 
reached an understanding with the government on the objectives, scope, and implementation 
arrangements for the TA.7 The missions also agreed with the government to adopt the TA's 
present title to reflect its broader scope of activity and its central objective to strengthen the 
supervision of the banking and microfinance sectors, and to build the capacity of the AMLIU.  
 
 
II.  BACKGROUND AND ISSUES 
5.  Shallow finance sector and vulnerable banking sector. With the broad money supply 
(M2) equivalent to about 29% of gross domestic product (GDP) in 2008, the finance sector in 
Lao PDR is shallow compared with those of neighboring countries—in Viet Nam, M2 is 70% of 
GDP; in Thailand, it is 105%. The Lao PDR finance sector has deepened only modestly over the 
past 5 years. Almost all financial assets are bank deposits (about 60% of the deposits are 
denominated in US dollars). Domestic credit to the private sector is also low compared with that 
in neighboring countries, including Cambodia. Explanations for the Lao PDR’s shallow finance 
sector  include  (i)  high  transaction  costs  for  financial  intermediation  because  of  the 
underdeveloped payments system, (ii) low creditor confidence, (iii) the slow pace of reforms of 
bank and nonbank financial institutions, and (iv) the slow development of infrastructure to 
support the development and growth of nonbank financial institutions. While the financial health 
of the banking sector has improved since 2003, it remains vulnerable to modest shocks as the 
capital base of SOCBs remains small as indicated by a combined capital–asset ratio of 1.77%. 
 
6.  Institutional and capacity constraints to a sound banking sector. Strong prudential 
supervision of the banking sector is essential to ensure it is sound. However, limited supervisory 
capacity, weak governance at the BOL, and low corporate governance standards at the SOCBs 
are major impediments. The prudential supervisory framework is outdated, and prudential rules 
and guidelines need to be aligned with international practices. The sector does not have a 
framework for prompt resolution of stressed banks. The number of trained bank supervisors is 
limited, and frequent staff rotations within the BOL are common. Public disclosure of banking 
data and financial reports of banks is also limited. The BOL's supervisory effectiveness is further 
undermined by the conflict of interest inherent in its roles as owner and regulator of the SOCBs. 
Best international practice shows that central bank independence is an important prerequisite 
for effective bank supervision and monetary policy management. Implementing governance 
agreements between the BOL, Ministry of Finance (MOF), and SOCBs is one approach to 
addressing these governance issues. The proposed TA will address governance weaknesses 
by assisting (i) the BOL in strengthening its prudential supervisory framework and capacity, and

(ii) the government in improving the implementation of the governance agreements with the

7.  Expanding rural finance and microfinance. While rural finance and microfinance in 
the Lao PDR are still in their infancy, serving only a small portion of the rural population, they 
are expanding and new MFIs are entering the market.8 The formal sector comprises the APB, a 
recently licensed branch of the Cambodian ACLEDA Bank, 27 regulated MFIs and savings and 
credit unions, and 12 credit cooperatives. In addition, there are about 5,000 small village banks 
that operate outside BOL supervision. The sector is expected to expand as some of the larger 
village banks register to formalize their operations under the new microfinance regulations. 
 
8.  Inadequate capacity of the microfinance supervisory unit at the Bank of the Lao 
PDR.  The  government  is  attempting  to  establish  a  more  conducive  environment  for 
microfinance operations. The updated national microfinance policy statement and action plan 
(MPSAP), approved by the government in 2008, forms the sector strategy to 2020. The MPSAP 
calls for an expansion of rural finance and microfinance to reach more rural clients through the 
participation of commercial banks, MFIs, and cooperatives on a sustainable basis under the 
prudential supervision of the BOL. The MPSAP also recognizes that as rural finance and 
microfinance grow in terms of the number of MFIs, lending volume, and product sophistication, 
this will stretch the BOL's capacity to provide sufficient supervision. Several weaknesses have 
been identified. First, a standardized monitoring and reporting system across the sector is 
lacking. Second, staff capacity for on-site and off-site inspections is inadequate. The BOL has a 
microfinance supervision unit of 11 staff under the Banks and Financial Institutions Supervision 
Department. As the sector grows, the task of licensing and regulating formal rural finance and 
microfinance institutions will be beyond the current capacity of the microfinance supervisory unit, 
and the BOL is considering upgrading it to a department. Third, microfinance regulations are 
currently applicable only to MFIs and savings and credit unions. To achieve more robust sector 
development, these will need to be expanded to provide the necessary legal framework for a 
broader, more inclusive range of microfinance service providers, including credit cooperatives 
and village banks, as well as support institutions such as network organizations, rating agencies, 
training institutions, and wholesaling institutions.  
 
9.  Anti-money  laundering  legislation.  An  AML  regime  is  an  essential  part  of  bank 
supervision.  Its  effectiveness  is  anchored  in  a  sound,  well-resourced  bank  supervisory 
framework with well-trained staff. The government issued the AML decree on 27 March 2006, 
providing for the establishment of a financial intelligence unit (FIU) and transaction reporting 
requirements for financial institutions, among other things. Established on 14 May 2007 within 
the BOL, the AMLIU is intended to serve as the country’s financial intelligence unit. It has three 
divisions (supervision and examination, intelligence analysis, and information technology). The 
AMLIU has department-level status and reports directly to the governor of the BOL. The Lao 
PDR became a full member of the Asia/Pacific Group on Money Laundering on 26 July 2007 at 
the group's 10th annual meeting in Perth, Australia.  
 
10.  Strengthening anti-money laundering institutions. The AMLIU is in its infancy. Its 
priority for 2009 and 2010 is developing the capacity of its staff, including training in financial 
intelligence analysis and report writing, which are necessary for the operation of the AMLIU. 
Training is also required in inspections and processes for monitoring suspicious transaction

reports and cash transaction reports. The effective development of the capacity of the AMLIU 
staff will require more integrated training. An in-house advisor is needed to interact with staff 
daily to ensure effective on-the-job training and effective implementation of the AML regime. 
Another effective way to build staff capacity is through short-term staff secondments to regional 
financial intelligence units (FIUs). The AML decree may need to be revised to make it more 
effective. Development partners such as the World Bank are assisting the AMLIU with drafting 
amendments to its legal framework, and the proposed TA will be coordinated with development 
partners working in this area. 
 
11.  The proposed TA builds on past ADB assistance in strengthening governance in the 
finance sector by enhancing the prudential supervisory framework at the BOL. The proposed TA 
is a precursor to the proposed finance sector program that has been included in the Lao PDR 
country operations business plan, 2009–2011. The successful achievement of the TA outputs 
and milestones could provide a basis for proceeding with the finance sector program.   
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The  impact  of  the  TA  will  be  improved  financial  soundness  of  the  banking  and 
microfinance sectors. The outcome of the TA will be improved BOL supervision of the banks 
and MFIs, and monitoring of cash transactions.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The key TA activities are divided into three components.  
 
14.  Component  1:  Strengthen  capacity  development  for  effective  supervision  of 
commercial banks under the supervision department of the BOL. This component will 
provide  (i)  on-the-job  training  for  bank  supervisors  for  on-site  and  off-site  inspections  and 
assessment report writing, and up to four staff secondments to neighboring central banks 
(Malaysia, the Philippines, and Thailand); (ii) enhanced procedures for bank on-site and off-site 
inspections and reporting; (iii) internal procedures drafted for developing a prompt corrective 
mechanism for stressed banks; and (iv) staff training on assessment of bank vulnerabilities and 
stress tests. 
 
15.  Component  2:  Strengthening  institutional  capacity  of  the  microfinance 
supervision  unit  at  the  BOL.  This  component  will  (i)  develop  a  standardized  industry 
monitoring  and  reporting  system,  including  off-site  and  on-site  inspection  manuals  and 
procedures, and corrective mechanisms for MFIs, financial cooperatives, and village banks; (ii) 
upgrade the microfinance regulations to a decree9 with possible inclusion of regulations for the 
establishment  and  operation  of  apex  institutions,  and  facilitate  training  on  compliance;  (iii) 
provide capacity training for the BOL's microfinance supervisors, including on-the-job training 
and exposure/study visits to different supervisory models in neighboring countries (Cambodia, 
the Philippines, and Viet Nam); (iv) support a study on upgrading the MFI supervisory unit to a 
department,  as  necessary;  and  (v)  support  a  feasibility  study  for  the  establishment  of  a 
nationwide apex institution to provide financial and technical support to MFIs.   
 
                                                 
9 In the Lao PDR legislation, decree is a legal document signed by the Prime Minister.

5
16.  Component  3:  Enhanced  capacity  of  staff  at  the  Anti-Money  Laundering 
Intelligence Unit. This component will support further development and capacity strengthening 
of the AML regime, particularly capacity development at the AMLIU in the following areas: (i) 
preparation of guidelines to implement the AML decree; (ii) on-the-job training for staff of the 
AMLIU in areas including intelligence analysis, monitoring and inspections, and report writing, 
based on best international practices; (iii) communications and media training; (iv) training for 
relevant staff in government agencies, as well as financial institutions with responsibilities for 
implementing the AML regime (this will include training on reporting requirements for staff of 
financial institutions); (v) design and development of an appropriate information technology 
system for receiving, storing, and analyzing transaction reports and procurement of equipment; 
(vi) preparation for the Asia/Pacific Group on Money Laundering mutual evaluation in 2010; and 
(vii) input to upgrading the decree to a law over the longer term. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $900,000. ADB will provide the equivalent of $500,000. The 
TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF–IV) for 
activities under components 1 ($284,500) and 2 ($215,500). The Cooperation Fund for Regional 
Trade and Financial Security Initiative will provide $250,000 for capacity development at the 
AMLIU under component 3. The government will finance the remainder, equivalent to $150,000, 
to cover the counterpart in-kind costs. The TA's cost estimates and financing plan are in Table 
A2.1 and a breakdown of the TA's cost estimates by each component is in Table A2.2, both in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  The BOL will be the executing agency. The Bank Supervision Unit under the Banks and 
Financial Institutions Supervision Department (BFISD) of the BOL will be the implementing 
agency for component 1, the Microfinance Supervision Unit under BFISD will be responsible for 
activities under component 2, and the AMLIU will be the implementing agency for component 3.  
The BFISD will provide office space with furniture and support services for the consultants, 
while  office  computers  and  supplies  will  be  provided  by  the  TA  project.  A  team  of  five 
international  consultants  (totaling  15  person-months),  two  national  consultants  (totaling  15 
person-months),  one  national  project  administrator  (totaling  18  person-months),  and  one 
research assistant (10 person-months) will be engaged individually to carry out the activities 
under the TA project. ADB will individually recruit the international and national consultants in 
accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). 
Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with the ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (January 2008, as amended from time to time). Equipment procured 
under  this  TA  project  will  be  procured  following  ADB  Procurement  Guidelines  (2007,  as 
amended from time to time), and the assets will be handed over to the BOL upon completion of 
the project. A project management unit will be established at the BOL under one of its deputy 
governors. The TA project will be implemented over 18 months from January 2010 to June 
2011, following the signing of the TA agreement between the government and ADB. Consultant 
deliverables are included in the terms of references in Appendix 3. 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $250,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Cooperation Fund for Regional Trade and Financial Security 
Initiative, and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a 
grant basis, to the Government of Lao People's Democratic Republic for Enhancing Financial 
Sector Supervision, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Component  1:  Strengthen  Capacity  Development  for  Effective  Supervision  of 
Commercial Banks 
 
1.  The banking supervision component will require consulting inputs from two international 
banking sector specialists (totaling 7 person-months) and a national consultant (10 person-months). 
The international consultants should posses experience and skills in capacity assessment and 
delivery  of  capacity  development  programs,  including  training,  as  required  by  the  technical 
assistance project. 
 
1.  International Banking Supervision Specialist (5 person-months, intermittent) 
 
2.  The banking supervision specialist (consultant) will have a postgraduate degree in banking or 
finance, and at least 10 years of professional experience, including experience in bank and finance 
sector supervision, capacity development needs assessment, and training for government officials. 
Work experience in developing economies would be an advantage. The consultant will: 
 
(i)  undertake an assessment of staff skills and capacity for effective bank supervision, 
which  will  also  provide  recommendations  to  the  Bank  of  Lao  PDR  (BOL) 
management on staff skill requirements, and develop an in-house training program 
and manuals for staff skills enhancement; 
(ii)  support  upgrading  manual,  procedures,  and  templates  for  on-site  and  off-site 
inspections and audits of commercial banks; 
(iii)  enhance staff skills in credit risk analysis, loan classification, bank stress tests, and 
early warning systems; and  
(iv)  review of BOL prudential rules related to cash ratios, capital adequate ratios, and 
rules and procedures for supervision on foreign bank branches residing in the Lao 
People's Democratic Republic (Lao PDR).   
 
3.  The consultant will provide 5 persons months of consulting services, starting in January 
2010 and finishing before December 2010. 
 
4.  The consultant is expected to deliver the following: (i) report on skill needs and training at 
the Banks and Financial Institutions Supervision Department (BFISD); (ii) training materials and 
completed in-house workshops on credit risk analysis, loan classification according to International 
Accounting Standard (IAS), and stress tests; (iii) upgraded manuals, procedures, and templates for 
on-site and off-site bank inspections and audits; and (iii) briefing notes on the review of the BOL's 
prudential rules. 
  
2.  International Banking Sector Specialist (2 person-months, continuous) 
 
5.  The banking sector specialist will have a postgraduate degree in economics and extensive 
experience in central banking, or finance and at least 10 years of professional experience in capacity 
development and training for government officials. Work experience in developing economies would be 
an advantage. The assignment is to identify key areas for Asian Development Bank (ADB) assistance 
to this sector over the medium term. The consultant will: 
 
(i)  undertake an assessment of banking sector performance since 2005, 
(ii)  undertake an assessment of the banking sector regulatory framework,  
(iii)  conduct  a  survey  on  key  policy  and  structural  issues  for  the  longer-term 
development of the banking sector, and

12  Appendix 3 
(iv)  update banking sector regional benchmarks for Lao PDR undertaken by ADB in 
2006.   
 
6.  The  consultant  will  provide  2  person-months  of  inputs,  starting  in  January  2010  and 
finishing before the end of February 2010.  
 
7.  The consultant is expected to provide one report on banking sector performance. The 
report will provide ADB with recommendations on areas for support over the medium term.  
 
3.  National Banking Sector Specialist (10 person-months, intermittent) 
 
8.  The  national  banking  supervision  specialist  (national  consultant)  will  have  a  degree  in 
accounting and at least 5 years experience in the banking sector. A major in banking or finance would 
be an advantage. The consultant is expected to assist the two international consultants and provide 
logistical support. The consultant will: 
 
(i)  assist the banking supervision specialist in undertaking an assessment of staff skills 
and capacity for effective bank supervision; 
(ii)  assist  the  banking  supervision  specialist  in  enhancing  staff  skills  in  credit  risk 
analysis,  loan  classification,  and  in-house  training;  and  provide  assistance  in 
logistics,  translations  of  materials,  and  other  guidance  from  the  international 
consultant; and 
(iii)  assist  the  banking  sector  specialist  in  undertaking  an  assessment  of  the 
performance of the banking sector, surveying structural and policy issues facing the 
development of a sound banking system, collecting data, providing translations of 
materials, and taking guidance from the international consultant. 
 
9.  The consultant will provide 10 person-months of inputs, starting in January 2010 and 
finishing before the end of December 2010.  
10.  The consultant is expected to provide input into deliverables of the two international 
consultants.  
B.  Component 2: Strengthen Institutional Capacity of the Microfinance Supervision Unit 
at the Bank of Lao PDR 
 
11.  The microfinance component will require consulting inputs of one international microfinance 
sector specialist (3 person-months) and one national microfinance specialist (5 person-months). 
The international consultant should possess experience and skills in capacity assessment and 
delivery of capacity development programs, including training, as required by the TA.  
 
1.  International Microfinance Sector Specialist (3 person-months, intermittent) 
 
12.  The international microfinance sector specialist will have a postgraduate degree in banking 
or finance, and at least 15 years of professional experience, including experience in rural and 
microfinance systems at the policy and institutional levels, and in capacity development needs 
assessment and training for government officials. The consultant must be well versed in Lao PDR's 
microfinance policies, regulations, and institutional context. Work experience in Southeast Asia, 
especially in Lao PDR, is preferred.

Appendix 3  13 
13.  Working closely with the government agencies assigned for the project, the international 
microfinance sector specialist will: 
 
(i)  conduct a sector assessment and propose a sector development strategy for the 
rural finance and microfinance sector; and will review current developments in the 
sector, identify binding constraints to sector growth, and outline priorities to address 
them in the short and medium terms;  
(ii)  review microfinance regulations and on-site and off-site supervision procedures, and 
provide  improvement  recommendations  through  a  stakeholder  consultation 
workshop, including a possible upgrade of the microfinance regulations to a decree; 
(iii)  assess  training  needs  on  supervisory  capacity  building  for  BOL  microfinance 
supervision staff, design a training program, and conduct the training; 
(iv)  prepare study tours for BOL microfinance regulators to different supervisory models 
in the region (Cambodia, Philippines, and Viet Nam); 
(v)  assess the feasibility of upgrading the microfinance supervision unit of the BOL to a 
department, and provide recommendations; 
(vi)  prepare  and  conduct  a  feasibility  study  for  the  establishment  of  a  nationwide 
financial and/or technical apex institution; and  
(vii)  guide and manage the inputs of the national microfinance consultant, and take lead 
responsibility  for  the  preparation  and  submission  of  the  inception,  quarterly 
progress,  midterm,  draft  final,  and  final  reports,  incorporating  as  appropriate 
contributions from the domestic consultant and concerned governments agencies.  
 
14.  The  consultant  will  provide  3  person-months  of  inputs,  starting  in  January  2010  and 
finishing before the end of June 2011.  
15.  The  consultant  is  expected  to  provide  the  following  reports:  (i)  a  sector  assessment, 
covering an analysis of sector issues, a long-term sector development strategy, and a road map for 
the  ADB  assistance  program;  (ii)  a  review  of  existing  microfinance  regulations,  and 
recommendations  for  improvement  aligned  with  microfinance  best  practices,  including 
recommendations on a possible upgrade of the BOL microfinance unit to a department; (iii) a 
training report, including training needs assessment, training materials, and study tour reports; and 
(iv) a report of the feasibility study on a microfinance apex institution.  
2.  National Microfinance Specialist (5 person-months, intermittent) 
 
16.  The national microfinance specialist will have a degree in banking or finance, and at least 
10 years of experience in rural and microfinance systems at the policy and institutional levels, and 
in  capacity  building  for  government  officials.  The  consultant  must  be  well  versed  in  Lao  PDR's 
microfinance  policies,  regulations,  and  institutional  context.  Excellent  oral  and  written  English 
communication skills are required. 
 
17.  Under  the  supervision  of  the  team  leader,  working  closely  with  government  agencies 
assigned to the project, the domestic microfinance specialist will assist in undertaking all the tasks 
outlined in the international microfinance sector specialist's terms of reference. Specifically, the 
national microfinance specialist will: 
 
(i)  collect government documents and sector data, and provide preliminary analysis 
and recommendations, as required; 
(ii)  organize stakeholder consultation workshops, training workshops, and study tours 
for the BOL microfinance regulators to different supervisory models in the region 
(Cambodia, Philippines, and Viet Nam);

14  Appendix 3 
(iii)  provide oral and written translation for ADB's missions; and  
(iv)  contribute as required to the inception, quarterly progress, midterm, draft final, and 
final reports.   
 
18.  The  consultant  will  provide  5  person-months  of  inputs,  starting  in  January  2010  and 
finishing before the end of June 2011.  
19.  The  consultant  is  expected  to  provide  inputs  into  deliverables  of  the  international 
microfinance sector consultant.  
C.  Component 3: Enhance Capacity of Staff at Anti-Money Laundering Intelligence Unit 
 
20.  This component will require consulting inputs from two international anti-money laundering 
specialists (totaling 5 person-months). The team leader will also engage one national research 
assistant (10 person-months). The international consultants should possess experience and skills 
in capacity assessment and delivery of capacity development programs, including training, as 
required by the TA. ADB will recruit the consultants individually basis, following ADB's applicable 
procurement guidelines.  
 
1.  International Financial Intelligence Specialist (4 person-months, intermittent) 
 
21.  The international financial intelligence specialist will have a postgraduate degree in banking 
or finance, and at least 10 years of professional experience in financial intelligence and in anti-
money laundering (AML) operations, as well as in capacity development needs and training for 
government officials. Working experience in the region would be an advantage. The specialist will 
work closely with the head of the Anti-Money Laundering Intelligence Unit (AMLIU). The consultant 
will: 
 
(i)  undertake an assessment of staff skills and capacity for effective implementation of 
the AML framework, including financial intelligence analysis; and this will include 
recommendations for additional staff requirements and staff training needs; 
(ii)  based on the assessment of needs, design and implement an in-house training 
program for AMLIU staff; 
(iii)  provide on-the-job training for AMLIU staff on intelligence analysis, monitoring and 
inspections, and report writing based on best international practices; 
(iv)  prepare staff for study tours and possible secondments to AML agencies in the 
region (Malaysia and Philippines); 
(v)  train for relevant staff in government agencies, as well as financial institutions with 
responsibilities for implementation of the AML regime (including training on reporting 
requirements for staff of financial institutions and public awareness workshops); 
(vi)  support preparation for the Asia-Pacific Group (APG) mutual evaluation in 2010; 
(vii)  engage a research assistant for 10 months to assist the project and the AMLIU; this 
will include drafting the terms of references and overseeing work; and  
(viii)  take  overall  responsibility  for  the  completion  of  the  assignments  under  this 
component. 
 
22.  The  consultant  will  provide  4  persons-months  of  inputs, starting  in January  2010  and 
finishing before December 2010. 
 
23.  The consultant is expected to deliver the following: (i) a report on skill needs and training at 
the AMLIU; (ii) training materials and completed in-house workshops on financial intelligence 
analysis, monitoring and inspections, and report writing; (iii) ensure study tours and secondments

Appendix 3  15 
are completed; (iv) training materials and completed seminars to relevant government agencies 
and financial institutions responsible for implementation of the AML regime. 
 
2.  International Anti-Money Laundering Legal Specialist (1 person-month) 
 
24.  The  international  AML  legal  specialist  will  have a law  degree  and  at least 10 years of 
professional experience in AML operations and legal policy advice to AML agencies in the region. The 
legal expert will work closely with the head of the AMLIU and the project team leader. The expert will: 
 
(i)  review  the  Prime  Minster's  decree  and  benchmark  it  against  regional  AML 
legislation; 
(ii)  provide  recommendations  for  strengthening  the  legal  framework,  including  the 
possibility of upgrading the decree to legislation, and assess Lao PDR's institutional 
readiness for an expanded AML regime; and 
(iii)  undertake up to two workshops on ways to strengthen the AML legal framework. 
 
25.  The consultant will provide 1 person-month of inputs, starting in January 2010 and finishing 
before the end of February 2010. 
 
26.  The consultant is expected to provide a report on the assessment of Lao PDR's AML legal 
framework, benchmarked against regional practices. 
 
D.  Project Administration Office 
 
27.  A project administration office (PAO) will be set up to assist the administration of the TA. 
This will be located in the Banks and Financial Institutions Supervision Department (BFISD). The 
BOL will provide the office space with basic furniture (desks, chairs, and telephone lines), while the 
TA project will cover the cost of running the office. A project officer will be engaged for 18 person-
months. The project officer should have at least a bachelor's degree. Some experience on an ADB 
project would be an advantage. The project officer will be responsible to and report to the ADB 
project team leaders under the respective components. The project officer will: 
 
(i)  set  up  the  PAO  office  at  BFISD  and  procure  the  necessary  office  equipment 
(computers, photocopy machine, scanner, fax); 
(ii)  maintain all PAO financial accounts and liquidate PAO office expenses using the 
advance payment facility, and maintain a bank account for office funds; and  
(iii)  provide  logistical  support  to  all  consultants  on  the  project,  including  making 
appointments, and organizing workshops and seminars.  
 
28.  The project officer will provide 18 person-months of inputs, starting in January 2010 and 
finishing before the end of June 2011.
